Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Phenotypic and Genetic Basis of Facilitation and Competition in Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants growing in the same place harm each other when there are not enough resources such as nutrients and sunlight to go around. This means poor competitors are at the mercy of superior ones, and less likely to survive and reproduce. On the flip side, plants can actually protect each other when faced with environmental stress such as drought. By blocking sunlight from reaching and heating the soil, plants that are growing close together prevent the evaporation of soil moisture. But since environments are constantly changing, a single plant can receive both harm and protection from neighbors over its lifetime. These dynamic neighbor relationships raise many intriguing questions. What makes some plants good competitors, but makes others rely on protection from their neighbors? How much do genetics versus the environment (nature versus nurture) control whether plants will harm or protect each other? Do harm and protection cause plant traits to evolve? The researchers aim to identify environmental conditions, plant traits, and genes that cause harm and protection, and use this information to determine if these plant interactions affect evolution. By identifying conditions that reduce harm, this research helps ecologists working to develop better methods to protect endangered species that are poor competitors. The results also can be used to breed crops that can survive and make food even when resources are low and stress is high.

The researchers are combining manipulations of the environment with selection analysis and other quantitative genetics techniques (e.g. analyses of trait co-variances) to connect competition (harm) and facilitation (protection) with natural selection and adaptation in Arabidopsis thaliana (Brassicaceae). Changes in light, moisture, and temperature caused by neighbors are being linked with the effects of those neighbors on the survival and reproduction of focal plants. Genome-wide association mapping is being used to identify genes for competition and facilitation as those explaining differences in survival and reproduction in the presence versus absence of neighbors. Once all these analyses are complete, the researchers plan to use previous knowledge of gene function to test the hypothesis that genes controlling nutrient processing and requirements, phenology, and stress tolerance also control competition and facilitation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The time when organisms leave stages of developmental arrest (e.g., seed dormancy in plants, hibernation in mammals, and the egg stage in birds and insects) is important. Emerging too early or too late may expose sensitive stages (e.g., juveniles) to poor environmental conditions. Emerging too late carries the additional risk of forcing individuals to compete with neighbors that already emerged, took up resources, and grew large. However, stresses in the environment like drought, cold temperatures, and predators often reduce competition among individuals and instead cause them to interact positively. Examples of such positive (facilitative) interactions include protecting each other from predators and modifying the physical environment in such a way that stress is reduced. Understanding the relationship between emergence time and the balance of competition and facilitation is key to predicting how species and communities will respond to environmental change. Furthermore, understanding the ways in which weeds of crop fields may interact with each other and with the crops as well as the degree to which these interactions are mediated by the emergence times of the crops and weeds could inform management plans seeking to maximize crop production. Crucial questions related to these topics include (1) Does facilitation reduce the risk associated with emerging early or late? (2) How do emergence time and interactions with neighbors jointly affect the survival, growth, and reproduction of organisms? And (3) can emergence timing respond to neighbors in the environment to ensure that young offspring experience less competition but potentially more facilitation?

 

This project focused on the timing of seed germination in plants to address two fundamental, interrelated aims: (A) characterize the ways in which the germination of seeds responds to nearby neighbors and (B) elucidate how germination responses to neighbors affect interactions with those neighbors, and more specifically, determine whether seeds respond to neighbors in a way that reduces competition, increases facilitation, and thereby improves performance. The research conducted as part of this project used the annual plant Arabidopsis thaliana as an ecological model.

 

Regarding the first aim, this research revealed that seeds germinate later if they detect neighbors in their own environments but earlier if their parents had neighbors. In other words, the times that offspring emerged depended strongly on the conditions their parents experienced. The ability to use information about the environment in both the offspring and parental generations may allow organisms to express traits or characteristics that are well matched to the environments where they find themselves. Such phenotypic plasticity can help ensure that organisms successfully reproduce. Moreover, the germination responses to neighbors in the seed environment were extremely variable among natural genotypes, which indicates that these responses of germination time to neighbors may evolve to match local environmental conditions, or at least that they could evolve, given strong enough selection pressure.

 

Regarding the second aim, this research revealed that delaying germination within the germination season or even across years may be beneficial by increasing the propensity for facilitation from neighbors or by reducing the negative effects of competition that occur among individuals within a population. Specifically, germinating later in the season, by exposing seedlings to cold temperatures and larger neighbors (i.e., better protectors), can increase survival. Germinating earlier in the season, on the other hand, can lead to competition when focal individuals become adults, unless temperatures are sufficiently warm to cause stress and induce facilitation. For populations that undergo a switch from intraspecific facilitation among seedlings to intraspecific competition among adults, a higher investment in seed dormancy (i.e., more-delayed germination) increases population size and reduces extinction risk by reducing the number of seedlings around to facilitate each other and thus the potential for high adult density to cause extremely strong competition.

 

The research made possible by this funding greatly advances our understanding of how biotic interactions both affect and are affected by phenotypic plasticity in the timing of emergence. Interactions among organisms depend on both the absolute time (i.e., calendar date) when emergence occurs, which determines the seasonal physical conditions that young organisms experience, and on the relative time (i.e., earlier or later than neighbors), which determines how big neighbors are. Notably, our results also revealed that these interactions change as individuals age, with older, less sensitive organisms being more likely to experience competition and younger, more sensitive organisms being more likely to experience facilitation.

 

Overall, this project advanced our knowledge of the role of time (e.g., phenology, ontogeny, seasons, and generations) in determining the outcome of biotic interactions. Because the timing of life history events (phenology), such as emergence, is tied to the environment, changes in the environment will yield changes in phenology that, as we have shown through this research, will alter how species interact with each other. These environmental change-induced disruptions in current communities will almost certainly have profound (positive and/or negative) consequences for those communities.
